title.narrative: Enhancing practical and technical skills in a modern and market-responsive potato sector, to increase production and employment in Tanzania

description.narrative:
Long-term impact
End hunger achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture (SDG 2). The Long-term impact is defined as follows:
Long-term benefit for the target group or wider benefit for the community in general.
1. Reduce malnutrition 1. Ecologically sustainable food systems
Long-term indicators
200 existing farms have doubled their productivity, and 100 new farms have been set up within 10 years after the project ends
​
​

The aim of this project is to create a public private partnership (triple helix approach) in which all of the participants have their own specific input, role and perspective. The partners in the professional network (output 1) make sure that training courses are based on the demands of the private sector and includes practical real life assignments (output 2). Staff members update their content knowledge and training methods regularly through their national and international relationships (output 3). The training institutions make sure that their education leads to graduates with entrepreneurial skills (output 4) and their courses are provided in a gender sensitive and inclusive learning environment (output 5).

participating-org.narrative: Mbeya University of Science and Technology (Department of Energy and production engineering.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: undefined
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative:
In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value: Achievements on projects outputs/outcomes are described in the logical framework format attached.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: 9 staff members from MATI Uyole are trained (5 male, 4 female), 14 staff members of MUST are trained (8 male, 6 female).

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: All female staff members working at the departments are part of the training activities.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: All staff members could use their acquired knowledge/skills in potato production, most of them could use the skills on how to build a strong institutional network.

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: All staff members gave positive feedback on the evaluation forms at the end of the training session.

title.narrative: B.I.5. % of scholarships awarded to minorities

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: All trainings are open to representatives from minorities, but at this moment there are no staff member from minorities working at MATI Uyole or MUST. However, we have selected very young staff members (some of them only started working at the institutes a couple of months ago) which is not very common to do.

title.narrative: B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: MATI Uyole and MUST have both developed a gender strategy but did not implemented them yet, this will be done in 2021

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: MATI Uyole: potato production, networking, development digital teaching tools MUST: potato production, networking, curriculum development, development digital teaching tools Stawisha: development communication tools for marketing purposes HUAS: providing training in development digital teaching tools Aeres: Developing cases about potato production in Tanzania in Dutch curriculum

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: One female staff member is promoted to become the institutional gender coordinator (MATI Uyole) and one female staff member became the departmental resource mobilization coordinator (MUST)

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: One of the female staff members of MUST who was several months pregnant got the chance to participate in the potato training. For MATI stimulating measures are expected as result of the implementation of the gender plan.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: Staff members who attended the potato course, video course and agribusiness course can implement their knowledge immediately after the course. Staff members who took the network course can partly implement the knowledge after the course as the institutions are still working on the development of the networks.

title.narrative: B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities

comment.narrative: 04-03-2021: There are no representatives of minorities working at MATI Uyole and MUST, but very young staff members have been selected to take be part of the training activities.

title.narrative: B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace
FNS.1 Reduce malnutrition
FNS.1.1. Number of undernourished people with improved food intake
FNS.1.2. Number of undernourished people with improved access to healthy/diverse food
FNS.1.3. Number of undernourished people whose nutritional situation became more resilient to shocks
FNS.3 Create ecologically sustainable food systems
FNS.3.1. Number of hectares of farmland used more eco-friendly
FNS.3.2. Number of hectares of farmland that become part of improved watershed/landschape management
FNS.3.3. Number of hectares of farmland that agro-ecologically became more resilient to shocks
II. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable
II.P.8. Number of staff of Dutch training education organisations that have gained new insights and ways of working
II.P.6. Number of scholarship holders that became members of the alumni association of their host university (of applied sciences)
II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods
II.P.1. Number of MoUs or other types of formal collaboration agreements exist 1, 3, 5 years after end of project
III. Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce
III.I.2. % of alumni promoted to more strategic positions within their own organisation or other organisation
III.O.2. % of alumni still employed by the organisation that nominated them
III.I.1. % of alumni who state that they have applied in their workplace the knowledge and skills gained from the interventions
III.O.3. % employers that states that their department/organisation has become more effective because of OKP intervention
III.O.1. % employer satisfaction on suitability of the training for the organisation
III.O.5. % of alumni who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
III.I.3. Narratives from alumni on policy and procedural changes, inclusive development, and innovations as a result of interventions
III.O.4. Testimonials from employers on organisational changes (implemented procedure/techniques, work ethic etc.) due to trained staff (critical mass)
